Research article Organic–inorganic hybridization boosts the catalytic performance of Mn-based catalysts in the aerobic oxidation of benzylic and allylic C–H bonds Anwei Wang Methodology Writing – original draft Data curation Visualization Xue Zhou Data curation Methodology Qianrui Yu Methodology Validation Yujie Chen Investigation Software Jiaji Bian Visualization Investigation Junfeng Qian Project administration Resources Qun Chen Project administration Resources Mingyang He Project administration Resources Conceptualization ⁎ Weiyou Zhou Project administration Writing – review & editing Conceptualization ⁎ Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Changzhou University, 213164 Changzhou, China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology Changzhou University Changzhou 213164 China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Changzhou University, 213164 Changzhou, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract An exciting and unprecedented hybrid material is contrived from layered double hydroxide (LDH) and organic acid. The hybrid exhibits significantly high catalytic activity in the C(sp3)−H bonds oxidation via switching the reaction path of Hydrogen Atom Transfer for the LDH precursor to the Proton-coupled Electron Transfer process. An unprecedented organic–inorganic hybrid material (BA-Ni2Mg2Mn) has been contrived using Ni2Mg2Mn layered double hydroxide (LDH) and benzoic acid as the precursors. The hybrid exhibited significantly higher catalytic activity than the precursor in the C(sp3)–H bonds oxidation via switching the reaction path of HAT (hydrogen atom transfer) for the Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH to PCET (proton-coupled electron transfer) process. The turnover frequency (TOF) value significantly boosted from 27 h−1 for Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH to 882 h−1 for the hybrid material in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl methyl ether, which exceeds most reported catalysts. The characterization suggested that metal cations in hybrid coordinated with carboxylic acid in a monodentate manner, which would elevate the positive charge of Mn3+ species and the surface basicity probably related to M–O2– structure. These improved properties facilitated the electron transfer and the proton transfer during the PCET process, respectively, and were responsible for the boosting catalytic performance for the hybrid in the aerobic oxidation of C(sp3)–H bonds. Various substrates can be tolerated by the present catalytic system, allowing the efficient synthesis of some valuable molecules over an extremely convenient reaction system employing molecular oxygen as the sole oxidant. Keywords Organic–inorganic hybrid material C(sp3)–H bonds oxidation Proton-coupled electron transfer process Aerobic oxidation Manganese Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Oxidation, as a ubiquitous process in the living world, is fundamental to much of biology and chemistry, and plays a pivotal role in the current chemical industry [1,2]. The efficient and selective oxidation of C(sp3)–H bonds has been a critical and challenging research topic. Compared to peroxide oxidants, molecular oxygen is the ideal oxidant for its low cost and environmental benignity, and has been a highly appealing industry reagent [3–9]. Thus, chemists have always aimed to develop simple and convenient heterogeneous catalytic systems for the highly efficient aerobic oxidation of C(sp3)–H bonds. Although extensive use of HAT (hydrogen atom transfer) reactions has been made in functionalizing C–H bonds, the scope is typically limited thermodynamically [10–13]. PCET (proton-coupled electron transfer) process can address many of these thermodynamic limitations [12,14,15] and has thus attracted considerable research attention [16,17]. Ru(IV)-oxo complexes [18], CuOAc/bis-(methanesulfonyl) peroxide [16], 2-ethylanthra-quinones–HCl [19], Mg6MnO8-MA [20], and some recently reported photocatalysis systems [21–23] have been developed for the oxyfunctionalization of a variety of C(sp3)–H bonds based on PCET mechanism. However, some drawbacks including low efficiency, requirement of base additives, and high cost of noble metals or ligands are still remained for these catalytic systems. In addition, most of these reaction systems are homogeneous, resulting in difficulty in recycling catalysts and purification of products. From the viewpoint of sustainable chemistry, searching for convenient and efficient heterogeneous catalytic systems originating from readily available materials and molecular oxygen for the selective oxidation of the C–H bonds is highly desirable. The typical metal oxides or complexes cannot achieve the efficient aerobic oxidation of C(sp3)–H bonds through a PCET process probably because of their inadequate electron and/or proton transfer capability based on their characters of structure. In the present study, we found an unprecedented organic–inorganic hybrid material (named BA-Ni2Mg2Mn) that was contrived from Ni2Mg2Mn layered double hydroxides (LDHs) and benzoic acid (BA). The hybrid material exhibited boosting catalytic performance for the aerobic oxidation of benzylic and allylic C(sp3)–H bonds without any additives, which could be ascribed to the switch of the reaction path that from HAT for the Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH to PCET process. We anticipate that the present Mn-based hybrid catalyst for the oxidative activation of C(sp3)–H bonds will open up a new avenue for the future construction of efficient catalysts and development of synthesis protocols based on that. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structure and properties of the hybrid The organic–inorganic hybrid material catalysts were successfully synthesized using Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH and BA as the precursors (Fig. S1, see Supplementary Materials). The XRD pattern shows that all the diffraction peaks for the precursors disappear in the prepared BA-Ni2Mg2Mn, and a series of new peaks appear at 18.0°, 22.9°, 28.3°, 35.3°, 37.7°, 43.5°, 48.8°, and 59.8° (Fig. 1 a). Miller indices of these peaks are mainly referred to Ni/Mg/Mn carboxylates analogs, and a very small amount of NiO impurities. These values agree well with the reported values (The detailed crystallographic data are presented in Table S1) [24–26], suggestive of a mixed phase for the obtained BA-Ni2Mg2Mn. Blocky morphology is observed for BA-Ni2Mg2Mn (Fig. 1d), significantly different from the Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH with typical plate-like agglomerated crystals (Fig. 1c), further confirming structural transformation [27]. The photographs (Fig. 1h) demonstrate that the color changed from the yellow of Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH to the dark brown of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn. The TG analysis in Fig. 1b indicates that the total mass loss of the Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH, BA-Ni2Mg2Mn, and BA are 39.7 %, 67.5 %, and 100 %, respectively, supporting the formation of an organic–inorganic hybrid. The EDS elements mapping (Fig. 1e and f) show that the Ni, Mg, Mn, C, and O elements are dispersed uniformly throughout the material [28], and the content of carbon increased from 3 % in the precursor to 36 % in BA-Ni2Mg2Mn from the sum spectra, consistent with successful organic incorporation (Fig. 1g). These observations suggest that the newly formed hybrid should consist of BA and Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH. The contact angles (Fig. 1i) of deionized water on Ni2Mg2Mn-catalysts are 38.9° and 60.1°, respectively, inferring that BA-Ni2Mg2Mn became more lipophilic, suggesting that the catalyst might be covered with organic molecules, probably related to BA molecules. All the above characterizations indicate that organic–inorganic hybrid materials are probably generated from Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH and BA. Full-scan XPS spectra (Fig. 2 a) indicate the presence of Ni, Mg, Mn, O, and C in both samples, and the content of carbon in BA-Ni2Mg2Mn was significantly higher than Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH. For the Ni 2p spectra (Fig. 2b), the peaks ascribed to the spin-orbitals of Ni 2p3/2 of Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH and BA-Ni2Mg2Mn are located at 855.8 and 856.4 eV, respectively. For the Mg 1s spectra (Fig. 2c), the peaks for the two samples are located at 1303.4 and 1304.8 eV, respectively. The XPS spectra of the Mn 2p3/2 can be fitted by three peaks (Fig. 2d), and binding energies of ∼639.1 eV, ∼642.3 eV, and ∼646.1 eV are identified to Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+, respectively, consistent with the previous reports [29–31]. According to the electrostatic shielding effect, the reduction in electron density will lead to a forward shift of binding energy in XPS [32,33]. The Ni 2p, Mg 1s, and Mn 2p peaks in BA-Ni2Mg2Mn move to higher binding energies than the precursor, indicative of the positive charge density increase on the Ni, Mg, and Mn atoms in the newly formed material. These results infer that the metals in BA-Ni2Mg2Mn might be partly coordinated with the carboxylic acid molecules, which elevates the positive charge density of these metals due to the stronger electron-withdrawing capacity of the carboxyl group compared to the oxygen atom coordinated to the metals in the precursor. The O 1s XPS spectrum of Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH (Fig. 2e) can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 530.8 eV, 531.5 eV, and 533.0 eV, which represent the coordinated oxygen (M−O, M = Ni, Mg, or Mn), defective low-coordination O2− species and interlayer adsorbed water, respectively [34–36]. In contrast, as displayed in the BA-Ni2Mg2Mn sample (Fig. 2e), the O 1s spectrum can be partitioned into four components. The 530.6 eV and 531.3 eV peaks correspond to coordinated oxygen (M–O) and defective low-coordination O2− species, respectively [36,37]. The peaks at 532.4 eV and 534.0 eV are assigned to the C–O–M and carbonyl groups [38], further confirming the coordination of carboxylic acid molecules with metals in the structure of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn. Further support for this coordination comes from the C 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 2f). Analysis of C 1s spectra demonstrates that the BA-Ni2Mg2Mn contains carbon atoms of aromatic hydrocarbon C–C/H, C–O groups, CO3 2– and CO groups [39]. The satellite peak of C 1s at ∼290 eV is a measure of aromatic, and the results indicate that benzene rings exist in the structure of the catalyst [40], while only interlayer anion of C–C and CO3 2– peaks can be observed in Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH, consistent with its inorganic composition. In summary, the O 1s and C 1s XPS results further confirm that the BA-Ni2Mg2Mn material is an organic–inorganic hybrid formed via coordination between Ni2Mg2Mn −LDH and benzoic acid (BA). In the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 2g), besides the peaks for the vibrations of M–O (M = Ni, Mg, or Mn) lattice [41], CO3 2– anions and interlayer water [42], the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of COO− groups at 1597 cm−1 and 1419 cm−1 can also be observed in BA-Ni2Mg2Mn, evidencing the presence of carboxylic acid. Furtherly, the difference between the two values is calculated as 178 cm−1, more significant than that calculated for the ionic complexes (136 cm−1, Fig. S3), suggesting that carboxylic acid coordinated with metal cations in a monodentate manner [43]. In Mn K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) of samples (Fig. 2h), the energies of the Mn K-edge of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn and Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH are situated between MnO and MnO2 references, and similar to those for the Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 references, implying that the average valences of Mn species are about 3+ [44,45]. In addition, a higher value of the peak for BA-Ni2Mg2Mn (6559.8 eV) than that of Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH (6557.8 eV) is observed, suggestive of an increased average oxidation state of Mn species in the hybrid and improved electron accepting capability. This is probably attributed to a reduction in the average electron density of the Mn center, resulting from the formation of PhCOO–Mn coordination and a more substantial electron-withdrawing effect of the carboxyl group than the oxygen atom in the precursor [36]. To investigate the local structure of the BA-Ni2Mg2Mn and Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH samples, Fourier transforms of k3-weighted extended XAFS (EXAFS) oscillations were conducted (Fig. 2i). Mn–O (r = 1.4 Å) peaks are observed for BA-Ni2Mg2Mn at the same positions as those for Mn2O3 and MnO2 [46,47], as well as the Mn–Mn (i.e.; Mn–O–Mn bond) peaks corresponding to the second shell [48,49]. The Mn EXAFS spectrum of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn is similar to that of the MnPc complex (manganese naphthenate) [44], suggesting their analogous coordination environment and local structures. Combining these characterization results, we speculated that Mn species in the hybrid are probably coordinated in monodentate form by organic carboxylic acids, including benzoic acid (41.6 %) and C2–C10 alkyl carboxylic acid (Table S2), which might be generated from the oxidation of solvent dodecane. These results are consistent with the FT-IR analysis, which contains the peak of 2963 cm−1 for C(sp3)–H bond stretching vibrations [50]. Based on the characterization results, the structure model for the hybrid was proposed as depicted in Fig. S1. To further characterize the electron transfer capacity of the hybrid material, the building blocks structure of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn and Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH (Fig. S4) has been optimized through DFT calculation using benzoic acid as a representative ligand, and the electrostatic potentials were calculated. The results show that more negative electrostatic potential (ESP) values around the Mn atom of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn than Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH (Fig. S5) [33], and the Hirshfeld charge of the Mn atom increases from 0.457 on Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH to 0.493 on BA-Ni2Mg2Mn. These findings are in good agreement with the XPS and XANES analyses, providing strong evidence that BA-Ni2Mg2Mn has an enhanced electron-accepting ability, which is likely associated with its improved oxidative properties. The surface properties have also been investigated·NH3-TPD of Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH demonstrates two desorption peaks at 134 °C and 300 °C (Fig. 3 a) [51]. Astonishingly, only a pretty small peak was observed at 84 °C for the BA-Ni2Mg2Mn sample, even when magnified by a factor of 20, suggestive of the very few acid sites. The results might be due to the coordination of organic carboxylic acid with the coordinatively unsaturated metal cationic sites in the structure, resulting in significantly reduced acid sites. However, no apparent differences in the type of acid sites could be observed for the two samples from Py-FTIR analysis (Fig. 3b and Table S4) [50,51]. The amounts of the basic sites of these samples were analyzed using a titration method to avoid the decomposition of samples during the pretreatment in CO2-TPD analysis. The total basic sites and strong basic sites of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn were 2.2 and 49.8 times as much as those of Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH, respectively (Fig. 3c and Table S5), while the amount of weak basic sites changed slightly. Combined with the XPS spectra analysis, we assumed that the strong basic sites were probably related to M−O2–(H) structure, and the coordination of metals by carboxylic acid in BA-Ni2Mg2Mn elevated the basicity of M−O2–(H) via promoting the positive charge density of the center metals. 2.2 Catalytic performance of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn The catalytic behavior of the newly formed BA-Ni2Mg2Mn was investigated using the aerobic oxidation of benzyl methyl ether as the model reaction (Table S6 and Fig. S7). Interestingly, BA-Ni2Mg2Mn exhibited significantly improved catalytic performance in the oxidation compared to Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH (Fig. 4 a). The TOF value boosted from 27 h−1 to 882 h−1, and the selectivity significantly increased from 60.0 % to 99.0 %, outperforming the previously reported heterogeneous reaction system with a strong oxidant [53]. The H/D kinetic isotope effects (KIE) for BA-Ni2Mg2Mn and Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH were calculated to be 13.6 and 3.4, respectively (Fig. 4b), suggesting that the cleavage of the C–H bond probably was the rate-determining step. Furthermore, a KIE value of 3.4 implies a HAT process for the catalytic oxidation over Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH [54], while a significantly immense KIE value of 13.6 for BA-Ni2Mg2Mn suggestive of a PCET process [55,56]. The changed mechanisms have also been verified by the model reactions using 4-ethylanisole and 4-isopropylanisole as the substrates (Fig. S7). The kinetic analysis of the substrate concentration indicates that the reaction order of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn (1.4) was significantly lower than that of Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH (2.0) (Fig. 4c), suggesting that BA-Ni2Mg2Mn is more likely to activate benzyl methyl ether molecule, which might be partly related to its improved lipophilicity [57,58]. The kinetic analysis of the reaction temperature was also performed independently over the two catalysts, and Arrhenius plots were presented in Fig. 4d. The apparent activation energies (Ea ) were calculated to be 49.5 and 121.4 kJ·mol−1 for BA-Ni2Mg2Mn and Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH, respectively. The significantly smaller value over BA-Ni2Mg2Mn catalyst than the precursor can well explain it is boosting catalytic performance and elucidate their different transition state and catalytic mechanisms. In addition, the newly formed BA-Ni2Mg2Mn also displayed excellent structural and catalytical stability in the oxidation. The conversion of benzyl methyl ether and the selectivity for methyl benzoate were well maintained after five successive cycles (Fig. S9a). Furthermore, no significant structural changes were observed in the reused BA-Ni2Mg2Mn catalyst, as evidenced by XRD patterns, TG, FTIR, and ICP-OES analyses (Fig. S9b–d and Table S10, entries 1–2), indicating good structural stability. In addition, ICP-OES analysis of the reaction solution revealed no significant leaching of Ni, Mg, or Mn ions after the catalytic reaction (<1 ppm) (Table S10, entry 3), further supporting the robustness and recyclability of the catalyst under the applied reaction conditions. 2.3 Substrate scope study The excellent catalytic performance of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl methyl ether inspired us to extend the catalytic system to a broader substrate scope. The benzylic ether substrates with various substituents located at the ortho-, meta- or para-site could be well tolerated, offering good to excellent yields of the corresponding esters (Scheme 1 , P1–P14). Relatively lower yields were observed for the substrates with substituent at the ortho-site (P9 and P11), suggesting the effect of steric hindrance. Benzyl ethers with long carbon chains (C4–C14) could also be well tolerated (P15–P19). Oxidation of the substrates with two reactive C–H sites could proceed smoothly and offer good to excellent results (P20, P21). However, only one C(sp3)–H was activated for S20, which should be related to the suppressive effect of the firstly formed carbonyl on the other C(sp3)–H. Oxidation of phthalate could give the corresponding lactone in an excellent 93 % yield (P22). Oxidation of S23 and S24 with naphthalene structure results in the corresponding esters P23 and P24 in 78 % and 70 % yields, respectively. The lower yield for S24 might be due to the steric hindrance effect from the 8-C–H bond. Isochroman and the derivatives could be well tolerated by the present protocol and give excellent yields of the corresponding lactones (P25–P30), obviously outperforming the previously reported heterogeneous reaction system [59,60]. Subsequently, ethylbenzene and its derivatives, whose oxidation using oxygen as the sole oxidant under mild conditions has been known as a challenge in the field, were investigated in the present catalytic system. Delightly, these substrates could be well tolerated, and good to excellent yields have been observed (P31–P42). It is also worth mentioning that a significantly excellent TOF value of 121 h−1 could be obtained for ethylbenzene (S31). Especially, the oxidation of 4-ethynylbiphenyl (S34) offered an excellent yield of 95 %, obviously superior to the reported Mn-based catalytic systems [61]. The substrate with electron-donating substituent (S35) was less reactive, but the oxidation of S36 produced an acetyl intermediate in satisfied yield with increased loading of catalyst. Oxidation of heterocyclic 2-ethylthiophene (S43) also provided the thiophenyl ketone P43 in 74 % yield. Subsequently, arenes containing different alkyls were tested, and we found that the length of the alkyls significantly affects the reactivity (P44–P45, 46–60 % yields) for the effect of steric hindrance. The yield of P46 was only 68 % because of the suppressive effect of the carbonyl on the activation of C(sp3)–H. Similarly, when substrates with two symmetrical benzylic sites, such as S47 and S48, were employed in the catalytic system, the corresponding monoketones (P47, P48) formed as the sole products in yields ranging from 78 % to 85 %. Furthermore, this protocol was also suitable for the aerobic oxidation of various diaryl methanes (S49–S58), resulting in the corresponding ketones P49–P58 in good to excellent yields (71–97 %). Intriguingly, the catalytic system could also give the objective products (P59–P62) in satisfactory yields in the oxidation of allylic C–H bonds. In addition, the oxidation of S59 gave an excellent TOF value of 889 h−1, significantly better than the reported manganese-based metal–organic framework system [62]. Interestingly, the oxidation of β-ionone over BA-Ni2Mg2Mn yielded epoxide P63 in an excellent 91 % yield. However, toluene, N, N-dimethylbenzylamine, and dibenzyl sulfide were incompatible with the present protocol and failed to afford the corresponding product. Finally, to probe the catalytic utility of the newly developed catalytic system, the synthesis of material intermediate and modification of biologically relevant targets were carried out (Scheme 2 ). 7H-Dibenzo[c,e]oxepin-5-one (P64), an essential intermediate for the preparation of curable polymeric materials [63], could be obtained via the oxidation of the corresponding ether in a 76 % yield. The BA-Ni2Mg2Mn system could also be applied in the oxidation of S65, a natural product-derived benzyl ether [64], giving the desired product a good 78 % isolated yield. Furtherly, three steroidal derivatives, dehydroepiandrosterone acetate (S66), pregnenolone acetate (S67), and cholesteryl acetate (S68) have also been tested in the oxidation system. They led to the buildup of structurally unique and bioactive potential ketones in 74–87 % yields; the hybrid catalyzed reaction system has the advantages of simplicity and efficiency compared with previously reported protocols [65,66], demonstrating the powerful synthetic utility and practical applicability of the present BA-Ni2Mg2Mn catalytic system. 2.4 Mechanistic investigation Some controlled experiments were performed to get further insight into the catalytic system. Significantly decreased conversion was obtained under the argon atmosphere, indicating the necessity of molecular oxygen (Table S11, entry 2). Relatively low conversions (< 30 %) were observed over Ni2Al-LDH, Mg2Al-LDH, or Mn2Al-LDH (Table S11, entries 3–5), suggesting that Ni, Mg, and Mn in BA-Ni2Mg2Mn might have synergistic effects in the reaction. Mn2Al-LDH exhibited a relatively higher activity, implying that Mn species might be the active centers. Introducing BHT (2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol) and TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl) could significantly suppress the reaction (Fig. 5 ) [67,68], suggesting that radical intermediate is probably involved in the reaction. By adding benzoquinone (BQ) as a superoxide (O2 −) scavenger [69,70], the conversions were significantly reduced from 89 % and 15 % to 21 % and 8 %, respectively, suggesting that both of the two catalysts can activate molecular oxygen to generate the reactive species O2 − during the catalytic processes. The conversion decreased from 89 % to 9 % over BA-Ni2Mg2Mn in the presence of electron scavenger CuCl2, while only a slight change was observed on Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH. These results demonstrate that both HAT and PCET processes are included in the BA-Ni2Mg2Mn catalyzed process, and the latter is the predominant, whilst almost only the HAT process took place for the Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH. Therefore, the significantly improved catalytic performance for BA-Ni2Mg2Mn compared with Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH should be related to the switch of the catalytic mechanism. Significantly improved oxidizing ability of the Mn center and raised surface basicity for the hybrid BA-Ni2Mg2Mn endow it as an excellent catalyst for the PCET process. Based on these experimental data and previous results [71], we suggested plausible reaction pathways for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl methyl ether under the catalysis of BA-Ni2Mg2Mn (Scheme 3 a). The radical intermediate I, which has been verified by the EPR analysis of DMPO-PhCHOCH3 (Alkyl free radical, AN = 16.1 G, AH = 23 G, Scheme 3b) [72], is directly produced via a PCET process (Scheme 3a and 3c). In this process, the positively charged Mn3+ species in the BA-Ni2Mg2Mn material accepts an electron, while the basic sites M−O2−−M (M = Ni/Mg/Mn) simultaneously accept a proton, leading to the generation of radical intermediate I through a concerted PCET mechanism (Scheme 3a). Alternatively, Mn3+OO active species was first generated on Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH [73,74], which then abstracts a hydrogen atom from the α-C–H of benzyl methyl ether to produce I via a HAT process (Scheme 3c). After hydrogen atom abstraction, Mn3+OO is converted into Mn3+OOH. Subsequently, Mn3+OOH acquires a proton and an electron to form Mn2+ and H2O2. Under the reaction conditions, the generated H2O2 is unstable and rapidly decomposes into H2O and O2 [74]. Subsequently, the intermediate I is trapped by O2 to form a peroxy radical II [68], which has also been detected by EPR spectra of DMPO-OOR (peroxy free radical, AN = 14.6 G, AH β = 11.1 G, Scheme 3b) [75], which then abstracts hydrogen from the substrate to generate hydroperoxide III. The oxidation product OPPh3 could be observed by GCMS analysis (Scheme S3) when the reaction was performed with PPh3, also implying the existence of unstable intermediate III [76]. The III can quickly decompose to an ester (P1) and hemiacetal IV, and the hemiacetal can further be oxidized to the objective product over BA-Ni2Mg2Mn. However, the hemiacetal IV can also transform into benzaldehyde and methanol with the catalysis of an acidic site and the further oxidative product benzoic acid (see Supplementary Materials for details) [71]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the excellent selectivity toward methyl benzoate in the BA-Ni2Mg2Mn system should be ascribed to its relatively low surface acidity. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully constructed a novel organic–inorganic hybrid catalyst (BA-Ni2Mg2Mn) via monodentate coordination between aromatic carboxylic acids and Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH. This hybrid material was systematically characterized and demonstrated significantly enhanced catalytic activity in the additive-free aerobic oxidation of various benzylic and allylic C(sp3)–H bonds. Mechanistic studies revealed that the catalytic enhancement stems from a pathway shift from HAT to PCET, facilitated by the hybrid’s increased Mn3+ positive charge, enhanced surface basicity, and reduced surface acidity. The catalyst exhibited broad substrate applicability, enabling efficient oxidation of a wide range of C(sp3)–H bonds, including aryl ether α-positions, benzylic, and allylic sites. Its practical utility was further demonstrated in the synthesis of valuable intermediates and late-stage functionalization of biologically relevant molecules. This work not only provides insights into C–H bond activation via hybrid catalyst design but also offers a promising strategy for developing efficient and recyclable heterogeneous oxidation systems. Ongoing studies in our laboratory focus on the preparation of phase-pure hybrids and their application in other oxidative transformations. coredata.dc:description: An unprecedented organic–inorganic hybrid material (BA-Ni2Mg2Mn) has been contrived using Ni2Mg2Mn layered double hydroxide (LDH) and benzoic acid as the precursors. The hybrid exhibited significantly higher catalytic activity than the precursor in the C(sp3)–H bonds oxidation via switching the reaction path of HAT (hydrogen atom transfer) for the Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH to PCET (proton-coupled electron transfer) process. The turnover frequency (TOF) value significantly boosted from 27 h−1 for Ni2Mg2Mn-LDH to 882 h−1 for the hybrid material in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl methyl ether, which exceeds most reported catalysts. The characterization suggested that metal cations in hybrid coordinated with carboxylic acid in a monodentate manner, which would elevate the positive charge of Mn3+ species and the surface basicity probably related to M–O2– structure. These improved properties facilitated the electron transfer and the proton transfer during the PCET process, respectively, and were responsible for the boosting catalytic performance for the hybrid in the aerobic oxidation of C(sp3)–H bonds. Various substrates can be tolerated by the present catalytic system, allowing the efficient synthesis of some valuable molecules over an extremely convenient reaction system employing molecular oxygen as the sole oxidant.
